turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We will hear arguments first this morning in Thomas against the Superintendent of the Ohio Reformatory for Women.
Mr. Stanley, you may proceed whenever you are ready.

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, members of the Court, if it please the Court, ladies and gentlemen of the audience, it is an honor to appear before the Court.
I understand from the clerk that this is the 50th anniversary of the very first argument in this building, so I am doubly honored that I am appearing before the Court.
I would first express what I would consider my mea culpa.
I wish that I had filed objections in this case.
It would have prevented having to come up to the Supreme Court for the decision in this case.
It would have prevented a lot of time from having to be expended on this case.
However, I didn't, and I think that given the case law involved in this Court and the circuits that it wasn't necessary, and I would like to proceed with the argument.
A little history of the case.
My client was charged with murder in Cuyahoga County in Cleveland, where she was convicted.

On appeal, Judge Krensler, who is now a Federal District Court Judge in Cleveland, held that from the current psychological and sociological research has emerged a profile of a battered woman as one who displays unique behavioral patterns and psychological characteristics as well as differences in reaction and perception, all of which are not within the knowledge of the average juror.
He concluded that without expert testimony on the battered woman syndrome, a jury would be unable to have a sufficient comprehension of the defendant's state of mind at the time of the homicide.
The Ohio Supreme Court granted review of the case and reversed the reversal.
I then went to the Federal District Court Judge in Cleveland.
It was referred to a magistrate, who recommended that the petition for habeas corpus be denied.
The District Court Judge had a de novo determination.

Notwithstanding the failure to file objections, the Sixth Circuit, implementing what is now known as the Walters policy, held that by failing to object to the magistrate's report, one waives the right to appeal to the circuit from the District Court order.
I then petitioned for cert and this Court granted it.
There are basically four points I would like to make on argument today.
The first and most important one is the interplay between the magistrate's act and Article 3 of the United States constitution.

When our forefathers were setting up the new government after the Revolutionary War, they were very wary of putting all the governmental power, basically the legislative, executive, and judiciary, into the same hands.
Accordingly, they felt that it was necessary that there be an independent judiciary.
They wrote Article 3.
Article 3 basically says that there shall be a Supreme Court and such inferior courts as Congress may establish.
It also said that those courts were to be staffed by judges who have life tenure and a set salary.
I must admit that Article 3 at first blush seems a relatively simple statement of fact.
It spawned a great deal of litigation in this Court.
I do not pretend to understand Article 3 and the litigation it has spawned, particularly in such cases as Northern Pipeline.
However, with regard to the interplay between Article 3 and the Magistrates Act, this Court has quite clearly stated what the law is.

Now, the Magistrates Act was provided in Congress in 1976 and subsequently amended basically to set up a series of inferior judicial officers, inferior, that is, to the District Courts, to help the District Courts with the overwhelming case law that they were being presented with.
Basically, they may consider nondispositive pretrial matters, conduct evidentiary hearings of dispositive motions, habeas corpus, et cetera.

In the section that we are dealing with here, that is, 28 USC 636(b)(1)(B), they can conduct hearings on a habeas corpus and then provide the judge with proposed findings of fact and recommendations for disposition by the Judge.
Parties may file objections, and the Judge shall make a de novo determination of those portions of the report objected to.
However, the last sentence, I think, is the key.
The Court may accept, reject, or modify the report.
This Court in several cases has considered the interplay between Article 3 and the Magistrates Act, most often through the pen of Chief Justice Burger.
The basic cases are the United States versus Raddatz and Mathews versus Weber.
This Court quite clearly has said the Magistrates Act is constitutional because the ultimate decisionmaking rests with the United States District Court.
Those cases basically came up with three points.
One, in going over the legislative history of the Magistrates Act, this Court has said Congress was sensitive to the Article 3 considerations.
They were sensitive to not putting in a magistrate Article 3 duties.
Hence this Court stressed and Congress stressed that the ultimate adjudicatory determination was reserved to the District Court.
The second point this Court has made in Raddatz and Mathews is, the Court says that the ultimate authority and responsibility to make an informed formal determination must remain with the Judge.
Three, the Court stressed the magistrate's role is one of helping the Court to narrow the dispute, focusing on the legal issues.
However, it again stressed the Court alone remains the ultimate decisionmaker.
In sum, this Court said in Raddatz and Weber, the delegation of the magistrate to hear issues does not violate Article 3 so long as the ultimate decision is made by the District Court.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Stanley, did you receive notice of the waiver rule?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: Yes.
In the--

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Did you request to file objections within ten days?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: --In the printed portion cf the magistrate's report, at the very end, contained what I now recognize to be notice that if I don't file objections, there would be a waiver.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Did the District Court give you an extension of time within which to file objections?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: Yes, they did.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Did you file any?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: No, I did not.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: How much additional time did he give you?

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Two or three months?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: --Two or three... whatever the time.
I don't remember.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: How would the District Court ever know that you objected if you failed to file any objections?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: First of all, if I may say, the issues were fully briefed.
When I filed the petition for habeas corpus, I included with it a memorandum of law concerning the issues I was to raise.
It was approximately 20 pages long.
In my opinion, this Court's decisions in Raddatz and Weber mandate independent judicial review of the magistrate's report by a District Court.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: On its own... on its own initiative.

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: No, on the initiative... what is included in 626(b)(1)(B).
That is, failure to object... the penalty for failure to object as enunciated by Congress is no de novo determination, he Court may accept, reject, or modify the report of the magistrate.
It seems that this Court has quite clearly said the Court must be the ultimate decisionmaker.
Otherwise, you have a situation where the magistrate ends up being an Article 3 judge.
For instance, in the Sixth--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Stanley, if you had filed objections, would you be here now?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: --Well, probably not, but hopefully I would have won down there and you would have accepted it anyway.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: All of this is brought about by your failure to file a piece of paper.

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And that is what we are using our time up for.

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: Pardon?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That is what we are using our time up for.

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I believe it is a much more serious matter than that.
Here we have Raddatz and Weber requiring a District Court judge to make a final determination.

The Walters policy as enunciated by the Sixth Circuit and other circuits in their policies have stated that the District Court doesn't really even have to consider the case if you don't file objections.
That raises a magistrate to the ultimate decisionmaker in a case.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Stanley, if you are right that Raddatz and the other case stand for the proposition that the District Court is an independent adjudicator, the adoption of your view would really allow counsel losing before the magistrate to simply go directly to the Court of Appeals without even paying any attention to the District Court.

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: Well, I disagree with you, Justice Rehnquist.
First of all, the magistrate's report is not a final appealable order.
Congress in writing the statute says, if there are no objections, the District Court doesn't have to make a de novo review, but the District Court still must consider the case.
It must be the ultimate decisionmaker.
The District Court then making an independent review but with the magistrate having focused the issues spends much less time on the case, makes a determination, and that is... it is from that--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But the District Court would surely be even more focused if it had the benefit cf objections to the magistrate's report from the losing party.

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: --I am not going to disagree with you, Your Honor.
However, it seems to me, for instance, in this case, where I had filed a 20-page brief, the issues were before the Court.
It was an issue of law.
This is the sixth court that my client has been to, that I have been to on her behalf.
To say that there is a waiver of anything is, in my opinion, untenable.
We have... I raised the issue.
I briefed the issue.
The magistrate came to a different conclusion.
All the District Court judge had to do is in fact what he did dc, Because he did conduct a de novo determination anyway.
What he did do was read my brief, read the magistrate's report, come to a conclusion.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, in this instance, how was Article 3 violated, because by your own statement the District Court did give review to the magistrate's finding here, and the finding became the District Court finding.

Now, if you make no objections in the District Court, if the proceedings at trial have been in the District Court initially, a court of appeals is not going to consider things that aren't raised at the District Court level.
Why should it be different with the magistrate's report that is considered by the District Court?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: Well, Justice O'Connor, if one reads the opinions in the circuits, there is only one circuit, the Fourth, which discusses this issue in terms of procedural default.
The Sixth Circuit does not talk in terms of procedural default.
The Sixth Circuit says specifically you waive your right to appeal, period.
Now, in a procedural default, you are not waiving your right to appeal.
You still have the right to appeal, but the Circuit Court says you didn't preserve it below.
It seems to me--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: The effect is the same.
In either event the Court of Appeals wouldn't be hearing it.
Isn't that right?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: --That's correct, but it seems to me in a situation like this it is a question of form over substance.

Where you have, Number One, a brief on the issue, the matters that are in issue before the Court on behalf of the petitioner and the magistrate's report, you have a right as enunciated by Congress to appeal from the denial of a habeas corpus.
That is an independent right that Congress has seen fit to give to a petitioner in a habeas corpus proceeding.
I don't know that a court can say we are going to ignore Congress and we are going to impose this penalty.
Further--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Mr. Stanley, did I understand you to say that the recommendation of the magistrate to which you did not object was nevertheless the subject of de novo review by the District Judge?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: --That's correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And does the judgment that the District Judge entered reflect that determination on that issue?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: The judgment of the District Court reflects that there was a--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: No, did it reflect the determination of the issue, the subject cf a recommendation by the magistrate to which you did not object?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: --That's correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And you didn't agree with that... the judgment in that respect?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: On the District Court?
No, I did not.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Is that what you wanted to have reviewed in the Court of Appeals?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: That is correct.
I filed a notice from the judgment entry of the District Court, notice of appeal to the Sixth Circuit.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Whether the District Court purported to review the report de novo or not, the only time that you get an appealable judgment is when the District Judge enters an order.

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: In any case, it is going to be a District Court judgment.

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And what do you say... why does that raise a problem under Article 3?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: Well, to be honest with you, Judge, as you pointed out in your dissent in Northern Pipeline, I am not convinced that I know what--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You are taking a lot of your time on this Article 3 issue.
You have got something else going, haven't you?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.
Only because Article 3 in interpreting the Magistrates Act has said the reason that it is constitutional is that the decisionmaker must be the District Court.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, it always is.

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: That's correct, and since the District Court must review the magistrate's report, whether objections are filed or not, it seems to me that the Walters policy and the other circuits are wrong when they say that there is a waiver of the right to appeal, because--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You have consumed 17 minutes now on this point.
If you want to save some time for the other matters, you should get on to it.
I must say that if you are right, then even if Congress said you either object or you waive, that would be unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: --I would agree with you.
A second point that I wish to make in my remaining 13 minutes--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I ask one question before you go to your second point?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: --Certainly.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Do you understand the Sixth Circuit rule to be that they think the statute compels a waiver, or that as a matter of practice in the Sixth Circuit we will enforce the waiver rule?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: Well, their writing, the language that they said was, although you may file... objections is something that you may or may not do, we feel they felt that under the supervisor power they could force this issue by making it a rule in the Sixth Circuit.

One of the dangers of that in my opinion, Justice Stevens, is the fact that different circuits have different rules for jurisdiction, and if we go to what was going to be my third point, which is that the courts cannot limit their own jurisdiction that Congress has given them, in different circuits some people can appeal.
In four of the circuits you can appeal no matter what the magistrate does, whether or not you file objections or not, you can appeal from the denial of a habeas.
In the sixth circuit you cannot appeal from a denial if you do not file objections.
In one of the circuits they talk about procedural default, and one of the circuits, the Eighth Circuit, rejects the waiver theory.
So, you have differing jurisdictions of the Court of Appeals as a result from these differing policies with regard to whether or not you file objections.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, there may not be a difference after this case is decided.

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: Hopefully not.

My second argument is a due process argument as it was enunciated in United States versus Raddatz by the Chief Justice, which basically says that what due process you are entitled to is appropriate to the nature of the case.
Citing Mathews versus Aldridge, it goes into the question of private interests, the risk of erroneous determination by reason and process supported, and the public interest in administrative burdens.

It seems to me that when we where talking about the great petition of habeas corpus, and where Congress has required the right to appeal as giving you that right, that due process requires in habeas corpus that the ultimate decisionmaking be with the District Court, and that the right to appeal be given to a petitioner.
I have already mentioned in reference to Justice Stevens' argument my third point, which is that I do not believe that the courts can limit their own jurisdiction.
I would say that in summation, that Walters is wrong because it limits their jurisdiction.
Congress never said in its statute that a failure to object is a waiver.
There already exists a penalty for failure to object, which is, you do not get a de novo determination.
The Statute says, if there are objections, there shall be a de novo determination.
That is the penalty for failure to object, not waiver of the right to appeal.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, you say you do not get one, but do you argue that the judge may nevertheless give one?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: No, I believe the judge may give... in fact, if the court... the court can do whatever it decides to do.
As the Chief Justice said in Raddatz and Weber, the magistrate is there to help the District Court in its overburdened case law.
It is there to focus the issues.
The Court can reject or give whatever weight it wants to to the findings of the magistrate.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Did Judge Conti hear oral argument in this case after the magistrate's report?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: No, he did not--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: So the thing was never set down on the District Court's docket in the sense of being kind cf a petition to review the magistrate's order.
You didn't submit anything to the District Court, and he held no bearing.

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: --Well, I will agree with you as far as the timetable is concerned.
There was nothing submitted after the magistrate's report.
The case was assigned to Judge Conti's docket.
I filed the brief with Judge Conti's docket, a 20-page brief that fully outlined our position on the issues of law.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Was this the same brief you gave the magistrate?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: Yes, so I mean when I file it it goes to Judge Conti.
Judge Conti fills out a little form and sends it to the magistrate.
The magistrate sends it back to Judge Conti with the report recommendation.

I would indicate for the record in... I was responding to Justice Brennan that two of the circuits in this country indicate that where there is no objections, the District Court does not even have to review the magistrate's report.
There is nothing more for the District Court to do in the case.
It elevates in my opinion a magistrate to a Judge.
I would reserve the rest of my time for rebuttal.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Aren't you going to argue that the statute forbids this, for heaven's sake?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: I thought I had, Your Honor, in the Article... in interpreting--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, Article 3 would make the statute irrelevant.

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: --Well, in my opinion the statute says, and right in conjunction, that you may file... the magistrate is to file a report and recommendations for final decision by the Judge, is what the statute says.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Isn't one of your arguments that the statute on its face and its legislative history forbids this result?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: All right.
Do you think there is any difference between the magistrate's recommendations on factual findings as opposed to points of law?
As I understand your argument, it makes no difference which it is, an issue of law or of fact.
There is no waiver in your view.

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: That's correct.
I recognize that four of the circuits have held that a waiver... that a failure to object waives the right to appeal factual findings but not of legal conclusions.

As Justice Marshall pointed out in his dissent in Raddatz, I believe that Justice Brandeis, and I would agree with him, indicates that in habeas corpus petition you are entitled to review of the facts and the law by a judge, and in my opinion because of the great place that we have for the petition of habeas corpus in our society, and the fact that we are talking about a liberty interest, we really must have a judge, and based upon the statute, which holds that the Judge is the ultimate decisionmaker, the judge must decide everything.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: One point.
Is your only point the fact that you don't have to file an objection?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: Let me make it clear, Justice Marshall.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That is what I am trying to do.

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: I would dearly have loved to file the objection because then I wouldn't be here having to argue--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, that is the only point that is here, isn't it?
Do you agree?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: --Yes.
Yes.
In my opinion--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You want us to say that the rule of the circuit is wrong.

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: --That's correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: In my opinion, yes, based upon the decisions--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, what part of the constitution does it violate?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: --It violates due process, and it violates Article 3 by practice of the policy, which is that you do not have... the District Court--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You mean Five?
Which one are you... which amendment are you talking about?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: --Amendment Five and Fourteen, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Five and Fourteen.
And that denies you due process?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: In my opinion, a magistrate... not having a judge--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Now, what else would you have filed with the Court under an objection more than the 20 pages that you filed?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: --Nothing.
To be honest--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So, what are we complaining about other than that you just don't like filing a piece of paper?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: --Well, like I said, if I had to do it over again, I would.
What I don't... what we... where the law stands now is that it elevates a magistrate to something higher than he should he by allowing him to be the final determination of the issue.
The issues were before Judge Conti.
He recognized that and he decided them.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You say that you wouldn't file it again?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: I said if I had to do it over again I would file them.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Suppose we send it back.
Will you file it or not?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: You tell me to file them, I will file them.
I will file them.
If it is going to cure the problem that exists and the reason I am here, I will file them.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I am still trying to find out what is here.

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: What is here is the question of whether or not the Sixth Circuit's determination in my case that I could not appeal from the District Court order is viable.
I say to this Court that my client has the right to appeal to the Sixth Circuit from the denial by the District Court Judge of a petition for habeas corpus.
They say that not... failing to file objections waives that right, and I say that is unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Mr. Stanley, was your failure to file objections intentional or an oversight?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: You have to understand, Justice Blackmun, I am an assault practitioner.
Up until Friday, when the Circuit Court Judge granted a stay based upon your latest Mitchell versus Wyatt, I was supposed to go back tomorrow to Akron to start a month-long jury trial.
I have to put out my time in each case as best I see it.
In this case I had filed a brief.
The issues were before the District Court Judge.
I felt to file an objection would have been just simply an exercise in futility, that the magistrate considered my petition, my position on the issus, and made his recommendation.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: So it was not an oversight.

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: No, it was simply a matter where I didn't feel that it would add anything to the controversy before Judge Conti by filing objections.
I would have simply refiled my brief that I had already filed.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Mr. Stanley, how is conditioning an appeal in these cases on filing of objections any different than conditioning an appeal on the timely filing of a brief or payment of a filing fee or something of that kind?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: Well, I think it is different because, Number One, Congress has given a petitioner for a writ of habeas corpus the right to appeal.
Number Two, Congress--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, even so, can't the courts enforce a requirement filing memos and briefs on timely basis and so forth?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: --Certainly.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: So why not this?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: Well, because this is where a Circuit Court is saying, we are not going to let you appeal because you didn't do something in the District Court, namely, file objections.

Number One, it goes to statutory construction of Congress's intent, which this Court has repeatedly said Congress's intent is for the District Court to be the ultimate decisionmaker, not the magistrate.
Number Two, the penalty for failure to file objections is quite clear from Congress's intent that you just simply do not get a de novo review.
There is no express policy outlined in any of the statutes or any of the legislative history from Congress that they expected a waiver of the right to appeal.
I would say to this Court that where you have a petition for habeas corpus and the right to appeal, that the Circuit Courts cannot limit their own jurisdiction.

As I pointed out to Justice Stevens, you now have a mishmash in the different circuits where in some circuits you can appeal, even though you have a failure to file objections, and in other circuits you can't, and I think that is untenable.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well.
Mr. Drake?

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court, the issue in this case is whether a Federal Circuit Court may condition appellate review upon the filing of objections to the report and recommendation of a federal magistrate.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Drake, the way you state the question interests me.
You are not contending then that there is a statutory requirement that Circuit Courts take this view.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You are saying it is a matter... each circuit can adopt its own rule.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: Yes, and I am saying the Sixth Circuit has adopted it under its supervisory powers.
The rule is--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: A permissible rule that is not required by statute.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: --A rule which is not only permissible, but--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Makes a lot of sense.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: --Fosters Congressional intent.
I don't believe that the Magistrates Act actually speaks directly to this question.
The question is whether the Sixth Circuit may do this, not whether it is compelled to do so.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And therefore it also follows, I guess, that it is not a jurisdictional rule.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: It is definitely not a jurisdictional rule.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Because they didn't make it retroactive, so obviously they thought they had jurisdiction to go either way.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: They made it prospective only to accommodate what I feel they perceive to be potential due process difficulties.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you think that... is their rule limited to the cases where the defendant gets notice?

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: Absolutely.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And is that your position also?

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That if he doesn't get notice, there can be no waiver?

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: The rule was promulgated in a case, United States versus Waltars, which is cited in the brief.
The rule was not even utilized in that case.
It was made prospective only from the date of that decision.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Then it is... you don't push for any wider waiver rule.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: No.
No, Your Honor.
I don't believe the statute compels it perforce, no.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So you... I take it the answer to Justice Stevens that other circuits could have just the contrary rule.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: The circuits could in their wisdom, I believe, though, if you look to the Congressional intent underlying the Magistrates Act, a circuit who declines to adopt the Sixth Circuit rule is essentially for reasons unknown to me fostering upon itself review de novo.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But it would be permissible, you are saying.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: It would be permissible.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You don't urge us then to try to make the rule uniform or not?

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: I think that if affirmance is given in this case, we might have more circuits adopting this rule in their own self-interest.
As I pointed out in the brief, the difficulty is not uniform to all the circuits.

For instance, the District of Columbia Circuit apparently has very little difficulty, if you look at the statistics, whereas the Fourth, Fifth, Sixth, and now the Eleventh Circuits are having considerable difficulty.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: At least there is a question as to whether this was a proper exercise of the supervisory power.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: I believe that is the only question before the Court.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And Congress did indicate what a penalty for failure to file was, or is.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: As to the District Court, yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why should a court impose a further penalty for failure to file?

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: Because the purpose underlying the Magistrates Act... and it had had a checkered history.

The original 1968 version encountered a series cf adverse judicial decisions, including ones from this Court, and it was in response to your invitation and that of the Chief Justice that the 1976 amendments were actually enacted.

The theory underlying the 1976 amendments very much parallels the master system user in the United Kingdom or the referee system used in most states today, which is to use non-Article 3 jurists, here magistrates, to delineate the scope of the dispute.
Oftimes you will have in a civil case a multi-count complaint filed.

The magistrate might recommend summary judgment as to let's say 18 of those, and the litigant will then have... essentially the magistrate will serve as a filtration system, where the litigant will then make an intelligent judgment as to whether or not he wants to proceed.
That is the entire theory underlying this, that the magistrates will filter this litigation in the nondispositive context.
The review is under the clearly erroneous standard.
In the dispositive context, as I said, the Magistrates Act did not fare well in the Courts.

They were very, very aware of Article 3 difficulties, and they made it absolutely clear that if the litigants so desire, he could obtain, he had the opportunity to obtain review anew, but he could forfeit that opportunity.
This case is tantamount in my opinion strictly to a failure to prosecute or any other procedural default.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Suppose the 20-page paper that he filed, suppose the first page of it said I object for the following reasons.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: In other words, you are saying, suppose the objections would have been filed, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Suppose he said,
"I object for the following reasons. "
That is all he put on the top of the 20-page thing he filed.
Would that be satisfactory?

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: You mean initially, when he initiated this litigation, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: No, Your Honor, I don't.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Didn't he file something with the District Court?

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: Your Honor, I think there is a misstatement or misunderstanding here.
After the magistrate issued the report and recommendation, the only thing he filed was a motion for extension of time.
He never refiled anything in the District Court, anything of any--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What is this 20-page thing he is talking about?

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: --When he essentially filled out the form, the habeas corpus form, which is provided for in the rules, and he also attached thereto a brief reiterating the claims he has made in the state courts--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You mean, that was a filing before the magistrate.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: --That was referred to the magistrate, yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That was referred to the magistrate.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: Yes, and considered by the magistrate in conjunction with briefs filed by the state of Ohio and a very voluminous transcript.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What did he file with the District Court?

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: With the clerk's office, when he initiated this action--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, I... the District Court means clerk's office.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: --Right, he filed the petition and a brief in conjunction therewith.
That is all he ever filed except for the motion for extension of time--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And after the magistrate ruled, he didn't file anything else.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: --Except for a motion for extension of time, he filed nothing.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: He filed nothing.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: Nothing.
Surprising, he didn't even file a 59E motion to alter or amend judgment, which probably would have avoided this question also, at least many circuits have held.
It wasn't too late even when the judgment was issued, in my opinion, but--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Why wouldn't it be too late, then?
Under the Sixth Circuit rule, it seems to me if you don't file--

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: --The Sixth Circuit has never really addressed the issue.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --As far as we know, the Sixth Circuit rule seems to be an inflexible rule.
If you don't file objections--

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
--First of all, the Sixth Circuit rule is not inflexible at all.

As I pointed out in the brief, there was a pro se litigant, and the Sixth Circuit found in that instance that there was cause for the failure to... the procedural default, and wanted to avoid a manifest injustice.
The rule is not inflexible, and we are not talking about jurists who are unreasonable.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --Let me just go back for a second to Justice Marshall's... I'm sorry... question.

If after the magistrate's ruling, your opponent had filed a piece of paper which said I object to the magistrate's rulings for the reasons stated in the memorandum I filed originally, period, that would have been enough, wouldn't it?

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: The Sixth Circuit has never addressed it.
What you are talking about... in any published decision, in any event.
What you are talking about is the pro forma blanket objection.
I don't know.
I can't answer your question.
I don't know if they would hold an attorney at law--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, that wouldn't even be pro forma, because they would have filed... you would have spelled out his argument.
Well, I see what your point is.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: --I think that in the case of a pro se applicant, that would be sufficient.
He is doing the best he can.
Here we are talking about someone who is admitted to the bar, and in point of fact Mr. Stanley had filed four claims.
When he went to the Sixth Circuit, he abandoned three of those.
Here we have a District Judge who sui sponte took it upon himself to unnecessarily waste time on three claims which obviously he had intended to abandon anyway.
The Act would have worked in this instance.

He would have filed objections in theory on only one of the four claims, and Judge Conti, who at that time had been elevated to the Circuit Court, would not have had to deal with 75 percent of this litigation, Your Honor, and that is what the Sixth Circuit is trying to do, not take away someone's right to appeal, but merely mandate that they perfect that right to appeal, and not... here we have not only a failure to file objections, but in the Sixth Circuit Mr. Stanley did not so much as file a reply brief indicating why he hadn't filed the objections.
Even though our brief dealt at length and initially with this question, Mr. Stanley did not appear at the oral argument.
The Circuit Court below had neither written nor oral explanation as to why these objections were not filed.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Mr. Drake, what about a situation when the District Court sui sponte alters the finding or recommendation of the magistrate on, for example, a point of law, and no objections had been filled in a timely basis, but the District Court on its own reaches some legal conclusion different from the magistrate's recommendation.
Would there have to be a right to appeal from that?

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: For instance, Your Honor, you are indicating perhaps Judge Conti would have granted the writ as to one of these claims?

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: Had Judge Conti granted the writ as to one of these claims, and I here have to speculate to some degree, because it has never really arisen in the Sixth Circuit, but it would be my judgment the state of Ohio could appeal, that Mr. Stanely could appeal raising as the sole ground for affirmance that relied upon in the District Court, and could neither file cross appeal nor could he rely upon the other three grounds that were not considered by Judge Conti.
I think that would be the logical extension of what the Sixth Circuit states.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And if a circuit nevertheless tried to apply the waiver rule, would there be anything in the statutory scheme or the Constitution to prevent it?

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: If the Sixth Circuit in the case where the writ is granted--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: --tried to--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Enforce a waiver.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: --I can't imagine myself ever making that argument, and I don't think the Sixth Circuit could do that.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, is there anything in the statutes or the Constitution that would prohibit a circuit from having so stringent a rule of waiver?

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: Would prohibit it?
Nothing would come to mind except for a general concept of fairness, Your Honor.
I can't imagine a Circuit Court ever doing that.
I am unaware of any remotely analogous situation.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: How specific do you think the notice must be?

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: I think it--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Here it was quite specific--

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: --I think the notice--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --but what if it weren't?
What if it were a general notice?

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: --I think that--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: That you might lose your right to appeal?

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: --Some Circuit Courts have had difficulty with this, and I think that the Sixth Circuit has taken the wiser course and mandated the notice be so specific that any child who really can read or write at all could understand that notice.
Here we are talking about some people that are in prison but aren't that educated, and I am certain that if you can read at all you understand what that notice means.
It is not ambivalent or ambiguous to any extent whatsoever, and I think Mr. Stanley's contrary assertion is sheer sophistry, Your Honor.
That is a very explicit notice.
And it is even in capital letters, as you can see at Page 50 of the joint appendix.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, if there were no notice, or if the rule did not allow an appeal in the other circumstance, I suggest, does that raise due process concerns then, in your view?

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: If there were no notice?
Yes.

For instance, in the United States versus Walters itself had the Sixth Circuit promulgated a supervisory role, and in that case it would have taken away the right, the government's right to appeal, as it turns out, but had it gone the other way, I do see due process concerns.
I think that notice is absolutely essential.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: So far as notice, do you think that each individual attorney has to be advised by the government or by somebody, by the Court of their right to appeal from a judgment of the District Court to the Court of Appeals?

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
For instance, had there been a rule, any rule of appellate procedure is not obviously incorporated in every order of a Court.
Attorneys are deemed to be on notice, and are to some degree pro se litigants, are deemed to be on notice of rules that are long standing.
This Court doesn't for instance, send me rules of practice every time I come here, but I think that the rule... it is the wiser course, because we are--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I thought you were saying it was constitutionally--

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: --I think notice is constitutionally mandated, the fact that you actually put it in every pleading, which is what happens in the Sixth Circuit.
Every report and recommendation--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --Yes, but I thought your answer to Justice O'Connor's question was, if there weren't that sort of notice, there would be real constitutional implications.
I wonder how you score that with the fact that nobody gets any notice other than reading the statute of their right to appeal from the District Court to the Court of Appeals.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: --Your Honor, I meant that for instance if a Circuit Court came up with some supervisory rule that took litigants by surprise and made it retroactive to appeals which were pending, I would have some difficulty--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You are talking about kind of a judge-made rule.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: --Right, which is what we have here, is essentially a rule which the Sixth Circuit perceives, and I agree, is very congruent with the intents underlying the Magistrates Act.
You simply cannot have your Article 3 District Judge being bypassed and, sandbagged.
The idea is to serve as some sort of filtration system.
Congress certainly did not mean to aid Article 3 District Judges and to the detriment of Article 3 Circuit Court judges.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But of course Judge Conti doesn't seem to have taken advantage of the latitude which you say Congress gave him.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: He did not take full advantage of the latitude which Congress gave him.
Perhaps that might... I have no idea why Judge Conti did what he did.
It certainly was not incumbent upon him to do so.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Maybe he enjoys reviewing magistrates' decisions.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: I honestly do not know, obviously, Your Honor, why he did what he did.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, you certainly wouldn't need to reach any constitutional argument if notice weren't provided by the court rule.
All you would have to say or hold here is that it was an improvident exercise of his supervisory power not to require noticed.
You wouldn't have to reach any constitutional issue.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: I would agree.
Here notice, express notice was given, Your Honor.
Mr. Stanley acknowledges that he got the notice.
The fact that he filed the motion for extension of time, which was granted, is indicative of that fact.
There is no dispute that... the only dispute is his belated misinterpretation of what that fairly plain language meant, Your Honor.
But once again, I would point out that we are here dealing with a court who has decided to exercise its supervisory power.
Reversal can only obtain if that supervisory power is repugnant either to the Constitution or statute.
Mr. Stanley has pointed out no repugnancy that I can ascertain.
He simply disagrees with the wisdom of the supervisory rule.

Here I believe that, and I believe the statistics indicate that there should be some latitude here for the various circuits to operate in the manner that they wish to operate absent some repugnancy to an overriding statute or the Constitution.
And no one has said that this rule is mandated nationwide.
Some circuits, particularly the Eighth Circuit, obviously doesn't perceive the need to have such a rule.
If they want to allow District Judges to be bypassed, Congress has indicated that they can do so, I believe.
I believe that if the court below is affirmed, perhaps Circuit Courts will feel a little more latitude and be a little more receptive to the Sixth Circuit rule.

What Mr. Stanley is attempting to do is relieve himself of the obligation as an officer of the Court to apprise the Court of the fact that he is dissatisfied with a portion of the magistrate's report or, for that matter, the whole thing, and he is putting the onus on the judiciary to do his job.
This is precisely what the Circuit Court said we are not going to allow this to happen.
This is no different than any other legitimate procedural requisite.
It is just that Congress said to file the brief, to file a timely notice of appeal, to appear at a pretrial conference, to give discovery.
Essentially what we have here is a failure to prosecute, and we have a totally unexcused failure to prosecute.
I have no idea--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I ask... may I interrupt for just a second?

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Is it your view or the view in the Sixth Circuit that a District Judge acts improperly if when there are nc objections to the magistrate's report or file the District Judge decides on his own initiative to review the whole report and decide whether he agrees or disagrees with it?

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: I don't know what the Sixth Circuit view on that would be, Your Honor.
What Judge Conti did in this case is highly unusual, though, as a matter of common practice.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The force, the effect of the rule as I understand it, though, really doesn't have anything to do with what the District Judge may do.
He can still either review or not review his own election.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Which is what Congress seemed to be thinking about mostly.
The whole force of this rule is to protect the Court of Appeals--

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --as I understand it from reviewing cases where there was a procedural default before the magistrate, and it is irrelevant what the District Court does.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Even if the District Court writes a great long opinion, they will say we won't bother reading the opinion because of the failure at the magistrate level.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: I don't believe that they would say in each and every instance some inflexible--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, the general rule would be--

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --But this rule does nothing to protect the District Judge, as I understand it.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: The District Judge is... in point of fact what really happens is the District Judge ordinarily does not do what Judge Conti did here.
Put the rule is not designed to protect him.
I doubt if it could.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But the judge is free to do it if he has a new magistrate, he is not confident, or something, he could--

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: If the Judge, for instance, got a new group of law clerks and wants to let them practice, he wants to review these magistrate reports, he certainly is privileged to do so, and I would have great problems if the Circuit Court told him he couldn't do that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --The only time the judge is really required to give de novo review is if there is an objection.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And if the objection only runs... goes to part of the report, that is all he has to give de novo review of.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: Which... and this is a classic case, Your Honor.
There is only one complaint before this Court on the merits, and there were four originally.

Presumably Mr. Stanley would have objected only as to this battered wife syndrome question, abandoned the other three claims, with a considerable savings of time in the long run to judges like Judge Conti.
The judges should not be presumed to be forced or compelled to do what Mr. Stanley wants when the litigants are not before him complaining.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I interrupt once more?
If I understand your position correctly, say there is... the District Judge thought there was merit to one of the four claims to which no objection had been made.
The District Judge would have the power to grant relief.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But the Court of Appeals would not.
If the District Judge denied relief, the failure to object would deny the Court of Appeals the power to grant relief, if they enforce this rule just automatically.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: Once again, Your Honor, I don't believe it has been erected as an inflexible jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I understand, but as a general rule, the Court of Appeals said, we don't have to look at this appeal because there is this failure here.
Affirm.
Whereas the District Judge doesn't have to.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: You might well have a proffer here that Mr. Stanley was in the hospital, that he was ill.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The District Judge just might have been extremely conscientious and decided he wants to take a good, hard look at it, but the Court of Appeals would just say we don't have jurisdiction because they didn't follow this rule.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: Absent at least a proffer of cause and an indication of... you might even have, at last in the judgment of one of the judges below, some indication of manifest injustice, because he thought there was some merit.
I disagree with him as to that point, but it is the two prongs.
Here there was not so much as a proffer.
Your Honor, the motion for rehearing which was the first instance--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: No, but there was a proffer in the Court of Appeals, because in the Court of Appeals they said, look, there is a meritorious point here, and the Court of Appeals said, we are not going to listen to your argument because you have failed to object before the magistrate.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: --But there was... Mr. Stanley never gave a proffer as to why he failed to do this.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, he didn't explain his failure to object.
I understand that.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: In a motion for rehearing, Your Honor, he said, ant I am quoting,
"Counsel is the one who screwed up. "
That is a quote, and he did not elaborate.
Your Honor, that does not... that does not to me equate with cause here.
I mean, this entire case is to alleviate one individual in a habeas corpus action from exercising his duties as an officer of the court, and we are at the United States Supreme Court.
This is not a onerous burden put on counsel, Your Honor, in my opinion, and particularly--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Nobody is suggesting it is.
The point is, what is the power of the Court of Appeals when this set of facts develops?
The District Court is free to look at it, as I understand; the Court of Appeals is not, as a normal practice.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: --I don't think that the Court of Appeals is saying that the District Court can't look at it, Your Honor, if I understand your question.

They are saying that in what we consider to be this sort of a sandbagging scenario, we will not transfer ourselves into essentially the first Article 3 court that reviews the substance of these claims.

And as my brief points out, the circuits which have adopted this rule are the circuits which are inundated with precisely these kinds of cases, because certain circuits... for instance, the District of Columbia doesn't have that many prisoner petitions, I presuppose, at least according to the statistics, whereas the Fifth, the Eleventh, the Fourth and the Sixth do.
And again, I am not asking for some nationwide rule of uniformity.
I am simply making the point that I believe the Sixth Circuit has taken the wiser course.
And even if it is not the wiser course, it is not one that is repugnant to the statute or the United States Constitution.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, Mr. Drake, the Sixth Circuit, as I understood it, acknowledged that it had jurisdiction of an appeal, but it dismissed it for failure to make the objection below, just as it might refuse to entertain an appeal on other issues that aren't raised below.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: Your Honor, procedural default seems to--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Isn't that right?

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: --Yes.
As a matter of fact, Engel versus Isaac arouse out of the Sixth Circuit.
They had jurisdiction to hear those claims, but because of the preprocedural default, they were not... they could not do it essentially.
It is not the power to review here.
We are talking about the supervisory rule, which was only given after this express notice, and the rarity of these cases is demonstrated by this case, I believe.

I mean, you do not see a flood of instance where the Sixth Circuit has to invoke this rule even against pro se litigants, and as I have indicated, it is not an inflexible barrier, jurisdictional or otherwise, because they have at least in one reported decision granted leave to review those merits when there was a proffer of cause and a feeling that there had been an injustice by the magistrate's ruling, Your Honor.
Are there any further questions?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well.

turn.speaker: richard_david_drake
turn.label: Mr. Richard David Drake
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Do you have anything further, Mr. Stanley?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: Very briefly.
First of all, with regard to Justice O'Connor's statements, this, the Sixth Circuit's rule is not a procedural default rule.
There is only one circuit, the Fourth Circuit, that would cause a procedural default.
The Attorney General may be trying to translate it into that.
The Sixth Circuit says, under a supervisory power, you have to file objections or you waive your right to appeal.
If there is procedural default, there will be an order of the court, and then that should apply presumably around the country.
Here we have, if you are going to talk procedural default, in four the circuits, it doesn't matter, and in two of the circuits it does.
That doesn't make any sense.
Justice Marshall in your question.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But you don't say it is a jurisdictional rule, do you?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: In my opinion, form over substance, it is a jurisdictional rule.
You cannot appeal because you didn't file objections.
It is not procedural default.
It is a jurisdictional rule.
It is a jurisdictional prerequisite, is the way the Sixth Circuit put it in one of its unpublished opinions.
And in talking about the differences between the magistrate and the judge, the judge has the case from the beginning.
He never loses jurisdiction over it.
It doesn't go from the judge to the magistrate, and that somehow they are two different people.
The magistrate is working under the judge.
The judge has the ultimate determination.
The brief that was filed, presented, that is what we are talking about in this case.
Were the issues, gut reaction, were the issues before the trial judge, before the District Court?
Yes, they were.
I filed a memorandum, extensive memorandum of law.
This case has been argued extensively and briefed extensively between... and this is the sixth court I have been to for relief from my client.
Now, there simply cannot be a waiver construed from that.

As I said before, I am sorry I didn't file the objections, because then we wouldn't have to be here, out the fact of the matter is, the issues were before the District Court, and the District Court made the de novo determination.
Congress has given us the right to appeal from a denial of habeas corpus, and the Sixth Circuit in their role is trying to take away that right, which I don't think it has anything to do with.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Stanley, did you address the waiver issue before the Court of Appeals?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: No, it was never addressed, and I might say that I was ill on the day of oral argument, and after consultation with his predecessor from the Attorney General has agreed that we could waive oral argument.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Well, you did not raise the... issue in your brief.

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: I didn't.
They did.
There was never any reply brief filed.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: You filed no reply brief.

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: And you agreed not to argue the case orally.

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: Because I was sick on that day.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: CA Six never heard this argument.

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: Pardon?

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: The Court of Appeals never heard this argument.

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: I filed the petition then for rehearing making this argument, and they denied it, and that is what bring us to this Court.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: The petition for rehearing?

turn.speaker: christopher_danahy_stanley
turn.label: Mr. Christopher Danahy Stanley
turn.text: Yes, petition for rehearing from their denial.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
